ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Cantera 1.5.5, new simplified Windows build procedure - tested, problems and solutions
ygData.msgSnippet: Fantastic.  Thank you so much! I tested this on a XP machine without Fortran using VStudio .Net and was able to run the matlab and python example scripts.  So

Subject: Re: [cantera] Cantera 1.5.5, new simplified Windows build procedure
 - tested, problems and solutions
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=204994144
X-Yahoo-Profile: rahunt_xyz

Fantastic.  Thank you so much!

  I tested this on a XP machine without Fortran using VStudio .Net and 
was able to run the matlab and python example scripts.  So far I have 
only tested the zipped source code, and not tested the procedure with 
code checked out of CVS.

I encountered two problems, which I will document here and describe my 
quick fixes (better solutions are welcomed.)
1. PROBLEM: The first problem occurred at the step of building 
setup_cantera I get the following output
----------------snip -------------------
------ Starting pre-build validation for project 'SetupCantera' ------
ERROR: Unable to find source file 
'cantera-1.5.5\Cantera\matlab\cantera\@Kinetics\private\CVS\Root' for 
file 'Root', located in 
'[TARGETDIR]\MATLAB\toolbox\cantera\@Kinetics\private\CVS', the file may 
be absent or locked.
ERROR: Unable to find source file 
'cantera-1.5.5\Cantera\matlab\cantera\@Kinetics\private\CVS\Repository' 
for file 'Repository', located in 
'[TARGETDIR]\MATLAB\toolbox\cantera\@Kinetics\private\CVS', the file may 
be absent or locked.
ERROR: Unable to find source file 
'cantera-1.5.5\Cantera\matlab\cantera\@Kinetics\private\CVS\Entries' for 
file 'Entries', located in 
'[TARGETDIR]\MATLAB\toolbox\cantera\@Kinetics\private\CVS', the file may 
be absent or locked.
------ Pre-build validation for project 'SetupCantera' completed ------
------ Build started: Project: SetupCantera, Configuration: Release ------
------------------------------------ end snip ---------------------------
SOLUTION:  My solution was to edit SetupCantera.vdproj in a text editor, 
removing all sections referring to the CVS directories by hand.  I'm not 
very familiar with VStudio .NEt yet, so if there is a better way to edit 
this file,  let me know.

2.  PROBLEM: The second small error occurs when running the script 
run_examples.m in matlab.  Everything seems to be going fin until 
PRANDTL2 dies with something like:
************************************************
                Cantera Error!                 
************************************************
Procedure: equilibrate
Error:   Jacobian is singular.
Try adding more species, changing the elemental composition slightly,
or removing unused elements.

SOLUTION:  This is  *not* an indication of a bad build.  This only 
happens when PRANDTL2 is run with a variable directly after PRANDTL1, 
without resetting the variable g.  Insert something like "g=0;" into 
line 26 of run_examples.m and it will run beautifully.
  

David Goodwin wrote:

>I have just changed the Cantera version number to 1.5.5, and posted a 
>Windows source distribution at the sourceforge site 
>(cantera-1.5.5-src.zip).
>
>The big news: Cantera can now be completely built  from within Visual 
>Studio .NET, including the Python and MATLAB interfaces.  You can also 
>create your own binary installer programs (.msi files) and distribute 
>them to install Cantera (+ your own application code) on machines that 
>do not have Visual Studio.
>
>Now there is no need to have cygwin (but personally I would install it 
>anyway), or to do anything from a command line, or to have Fortran.  I 
>think virtually all Windows installation problems should be gone now.  
>(Also, the Python location is no longer hard-wired to C:\PYTHON23.)
>
>The procedure is described step-by-step in a Powerpoint presentation I 
>have also posted at the Sourceforge site under "Cantera Documentation" 
>- see file cantera-vc7.ppt.
>
>Other than that, you may notice a new class "Mixture" in Python, and a 
>couple of new classes (MultiPhase and MultiPhaseEquil) in C++. These 
>implement multi-phase mixtures and a new multi-phase equilibrium 
>solver.  It is fully functional in Python and C++ now (MATLAB soon), 
>but is not documented, so its official introduction will be in Cantera 
>1.6 which will be out in January.  Cantera 1.6 will contain also some 
>new phase models, and some improved support for non-ideal phases.
>
>Windows people in particular - if you have Visual C++ .NET, please try 
>out the new build procedure, and report any problems.
>
>
